sections.html:
Zone 2 • Experiments

Vortex & Spin Experiments

Protocols That Turn "Vortex Water" Into Repeatable Data

Vortex talk is everywhere. But without standardization, results are random.

This page converts vortex ideas into clean experiments with one variable at a time, consistent containers, and time-based logging.

Definition

A vortex experiment is a controlled comparison where water is spun/vortexed under defined conditions and measured against a baseline using the same fingerprint over time.

The Vortex Variables

What Must Be Controlled

  • Container: Shape, size, material (Glass vs Plastic)
  • Spin: Method, intensity (RPM), duration
  • Environment: Temperature (Log every time), Gas exchange (Open vs Closed)
  • Timing: Rest time after vortex (Immediate vs 30 min)

Golden Rule: Choose one method and keep it consistent.

The Measurement Stack

Mandatory

Temperature. Always log temperature.

Core Fingerprint

EC/TDS, ORP, pH.

Read EC Read ORP

Visual

Turbidity/Clarity.

Read Turbidity

The Baseline Protocol

Goal: Compare Vortexed vs Baseline

Setup: Two identical glass containers (A=Baseline, B=Vortexed). Same water, same volume.

Action: Vortex B (defined method). Do nothing to A.

Measure: At 0 min, 30 min, 2 hrs, 24 hrs.

Download Log Sheet Submit Results

Experiment Ladder

1. Hand Vortex

Use Case: Accessibility.

Method: Swirl consistent direction, count rotations (e.g. 60).

Note: Low precision.

2. Stir Plate

Use Case: Consistency.

Method: Defined RPM, defined duration.

Note: Best "home lab" standard.

3. Blender (High Shear)

Use Case: High energy.

Method: Short burst.

Note: Introduces heat + gas. Watch ORP drift.

Interpretation Guide

Pattern Over Numbers

When people say "vortex changed the water," ask:

"Which window changed: EC, ORP, pH, turbidity—and at which time point?"

Common changes come from gas exchange (O/CO₂) and temperature shifts. That's not magic, it's physics.

Gas Exchange Logic

Common Mistakes

1. No Control

Always need a baseline jar.

2. Different Containers

Material shape affects results.

3. Ignoring Temp

Temp shifts change ORP/pH readings.

4. Too Many Variables

Do vortex OR magnets, not both at once.

items.question: Do vortex experiments need expensive tools?
items.answer: No. Hand vortex with rotation counts works as a baseline—consistency matters more than fancy devices.

items.question: Why does ORP change after vortexing?
items.answer: Often due to gas exchange and temperature shifts. That’s why rest time and temperature logging are essential.

items.question: Should I measure immediately after vortexing?
items.answer: Measure temperature immediately, but define a consistent rest schedule for ORP/pH (e.g., 5 min or 30 min) and always repeat it.

items.question: What’s the best standard method?
items.answer: A magnetic stir plate with defined RPM and duration—because it reduces variability.
